Social media has amplified shame so much apologizing feels like a crime.

Genuine apologies followed by reparations for what has been done shouldn’t be made fun of or weaponized. We should be able to forgive and move on. Yet, here we are.

I’ve been in these internet streets for a long minute. When I say a long minute I mean over 20 years as an active internet user. Never before has the weaponization of what you’ve said online been as bad as today.

Along the way I’ve noticed there’s a disconnect in how we communicate and how we handle conflict.

Gone are the days where you can make an honest mistake, get made fun of for it, apologize, and then people move on. Today what you do on the internet can and will be used against you forever.

We’ve all seen celebrities and influencers apologize for all sorts of things from infidelity to lyrics in a song. 

We’ve seen public figures and companies do it to win back favor from their audiences. 

Some apologies make sense and come from a good place. Those apologies are made with the intent to correct for their mistakes however long it takes.

Others are done with clinched fists and tight lips to appease fans and to not lose consumers.

I’ve witnessed mobs of armchair activists demand apologies from people they found guilty in the court of public opinion. It can get ugly and people’s personal information often gets released.

After seeing so many people genuinely apologize just for their mistakes to be used against them in the future, 

I’m afraid the practice of healthy conflict resolution is corroding throughout our society. Mainly, on the internet.

This makes me ask: What are some of the things we can do to change this? What if we stood up for people who’ve already apologized more or don’t need to apologize? What would conflict resolution online look like in the future?

Let’s all be open to being more forgiving, defending those that are clearly being bullied into apologizing, and admit to being wrong on our own without outside pressure.

Let’s civilly discuss/debate below. Thank you for reading.

Why do you believe what you believe? How did you arrive at that conclusion? Do you have evidence to support what you believe or do you just feel like it’s right? Are your sources credible and are you able to identify the limits of your knowledge on this/these issues?

No belief, philosophy, or idea should go unexamined. Every belief you have should be investigated. To not question yourself does a disservice to your software as a human being.

There’s way too much misinformation and disinformation on the internet to not investigate. Like Richard Feynman says, “You’re the easiest person to fool!” Be your number one fact checker before relying on other people to fact check for you.

When challenged to elaborate on what we believe and support and why, it feels like a personal attack sometimes. Probably because there’s a part of us that can’t understand why people don’t already believe what we believe. Sometimes it’s because some ask questions in bad faith.

I hold the opinion that we should channel our negative feelings about being challenged into investigating our beliefs and opinions. It’s a great opportunity to grow and abandon any beliefs that fails to survive investigation. 

What beliefs have you recently examined? 

Let me know below. I encourage civil dialogue and debate so please be kind. But if you dish it you better be able to take it. 

Tags to ignore or explore:
#criticalthinking #philosophy #logic #reason #scientificmethod #science #scientificthinking #thinking #thinkcritically #logical #logicalreasoning #scientist #scicomm #sciencecommunication #scientistsofinstagram #physicist #exposed #debunked

Availability bias happens when people make decisions and judgements based on data and information that is easily available to them that is usually easier to understand, rather than information that is more complete, complex, and reliable.

It can cause people to overestimate the likelihood of situations and underestimate less likely scenarios due to not having the full picture of whats going on available.

The most recent and relevant example of this is sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in young athletes — a very controversial topic.

Reporting on SCA of athletes have went up in recent years causing people to question things about “new” medical treatments. The vaccine has been called into question the most by the media, people on the internet, independent outlets, medical professionals, and even scientists.

The most recent debacle with NFL player Damar Hamlin has caused concern in people worldwide. Since NFL players were required to take the vaccine most are questioning if that had something to do with his sudden heart failure. 

Damar Hamlin and local stories of children collapsing has pulled on the heart strings of a lot of people, but science isn’t governed by emotion. It’s governed by reality.

Is SCA something new in athletes or on the rise in general? Short answer: No and yes. That’s where availability bias can creep in and warp our perception.

What we know is since at least the 80’s SCA had been the leading medical cause in athlete deaths (O’Keefe 1984, Marin 86). There has been a rise in cases overall, but there are many factors to consider including viruses that attack the respiratory system.

In 2009 there was a study (Maron 2009) that did an analysis of 1866 athlete deaths in the United States from 1980-2006.

What it found was although SCA a rare condition to athletes in general it’s has been on the rise since 1994 decades before mRNA vaccines’ availability.

Not considering those facts & others is not a good way to think and can cause people to reach false conclusions. 

So it’s unlikely the vaccines are the cause. What is likely is that we, no matter our education level, are easily fooled by information easily available to us.

Questioning should be always encouraged. How to question effectively should be encouraged more. The problem I run into a lot are people who don’t question themselves because they’re sure they’re right. 

A lot of same people who will tell you to “open your mind” and “question everything” aren’t as critical when it comes to their own beliefs. 

These are people on both the right and left politically, religious people and atheists, scientists and non scientists, and more. Nobody is safe.

It’s hard to question things we think we know and things we love to know, but it’s not impossible.

My advice here is to be more critical of yourself and your own beliefs before you go out into the internet to criticize others.

Stay curious, my friends.

To say you don’t care at all about what people think about you is a lie. It might sound good when you type it into the void of social media or tell your friends, but let’s get real here. We all care to some degree.

This will be more of a rant than anything so if you don’t feel like reading you don’t have to.

Isnt it crazy when @anonymousbootylicker tells us we are stupid for thinking what we think, how we look, or how bad of a person we are it hurts, but the 20 other positive comments we ignore?

Most of the people with strong opinions about your character or who you are online will never see you in person and even if they did they wouldn’t have the confidence to say it to your face.

I know this because I have an open challenge to my haters and none of them have taken me up on my offer yet for a one on one fight in a boxing ring. It’s been open for 3 years. 😂

Anyways, I’m all for being civil and respectful initially. But once someone takes it to a negative place I don’t mind echoing that energy until they’re destroyed or retreats. 

I don’t mind criticism of my character or of the things I think. I invite it and appreciate constructive criticism.

What I dislike are people who are poor at reading comprehension, assume you’re a bad person because they disagree with you, or purposely misquotes you to exaggerate how bad they assume you are. 

I’m brutally honest online. That will inevitably come with being partially wrong, mostly wrong, or entirely wrong on any given issue. That will also result in me gaining friends, acquaintances, and also enemies. Those are things I will forever be ok with.

Criticism makes you stronger and enemies keep you sharp. I don’t self-censor because the artist in me won’t allow it. I’m not for everyone’s consumption and there’s a bigger part of me that loves that than the part of me that is concerned.

 I don’t look for problems but I do look for dialogue and civil debates. This is SOCIAL media after all. Why state your opinions publicly on social media if you are hypersensitive? 

I’ll end this with a quote by @50cent

“I don’t ever want a problem. But when they say they want a problem I say, “No problem.””

Stay curious.

Fact checking may be hard and tedious. However, being loudly and proudly wrong is harder and most tedious.

Always fact check no matter what your gut says. Contrary to popular belief your gut isn’t always right. If it were you would’ve never had a failed relationship. 🙃😂

What ever happened to just disagreeing and moving on with your life? Or, dare I say, remaining friends after disagreement? Why is that less common today?

Notice I said less common and not uncommon. The reality is most people are able to disagree without slandering people or hating them.

While most people often hang around people they share common values and opinions with, there are weirdos like me who have friends and acquaintances of all types of backgrounds with many different and even extreme views.

“So you’re saying we should be friends with RACISTS, SEXISTS, and HOMOPHOBES?” Of course your anxious mind goes to extremes but yes. I am saying that. 

As a matter of fact, I would bet my last dollar you already have friends, family, and acquaintances that believe in some really horrible things. You still love them. You still do things for them. You still tolerate them. Why can’t you be that way to strangers?

That stranger on the internet is human too. They have a job, have pets, have friends, have flaws, enjoys music, and more just like you. 

Its one thing to call out bad ideas and bad behavior. Some ideas and bad behavior by people need to be shamed. You’re letting another monster loose when you decide to slander someone’s character and to harass them into silence because y’all disagree.

The world isn’t built around your comfort and agreement. The universe is indifferent to what we find preferable. Most people don’t care about you because they don’t know you even exist. What you are offended by is none of our business.

What should we do about it?

Let’s call in instead of call out. We can call in to have a conversation. We can call in to understand one another’s position better so that we can see things from another perspective. Persuasion takes patience and consistency. Meanness takes little effort and that’s why most do it. 

How do you plan on calling people in more? 

Let me know below. Please be civil and respectful. Don’t dish what you can’t eat.

#civildiscourse #cancelculture #empathy #science

Intellectual honesty is lacking in the world today.

What is intellectual honesty? I define intellectual honesty as honest analyses with the goal of leading to an accurate exchange of ideas between yourself and/or others.

Why is intellectual honesty important? It’s important to figure things out personally and with others. When someone is intellectually dishonest that means they don’t value facts, logic, or accurate information more than how they feel about them.

It doesn’t help that we are often texting through a device that lessens our ability to empathize and understand the humans on the other side of them.

In result it’s easier to be mean, lack empathy, and not challenge our beliefs in order to remain loud but wrong because it makes us feel important. Misinformation is often spread due to intellectual dishonesty. Why correct information if you’re not honest about what you don’t know?

The repercussions for being intellectually dishonest are incalculable. It’s also hurtful to be on the other side of someone being intellectually dishonest. Unfortunately, it rarely overrides people’s need to feel pleasure from being unkind to a strangers, no matter how accurate the stranger is, or how wrong they may be about what they’re arguing.

What most people fail to realize is there’s so much power and more reward in intellectual honesty. Intellectual honesty grants us the power to improve our thinking and ability to know better so we can do better.
.
It’s ok not to know things. Everyone knows less than they know while having differing degrees of knowledge about different things.

It’s ok to investigate something you care about and find out you were wrong all along. Fact-checking yourself should be a regular occurrence.

It’s also ok to acknowledge good points from people you normally wouldn’t agree with. That only comes from tolerating differing points of view. But that’s a subject for another time.

Thank you for reading.

What do you think about intellectual honesty and how have you practiced it recently?

Just a physics student aspiring to get a PhD. Lets learn from one another.
